item.title: Mount Mountain Mountain
item.description:
An Ottoman Turkish tautology

Wikipedia has an article on a place called Pendle Hill, noteworthy, perhaps, mainly for being a triple tautology:

The name “Pendle Hill” combines the words for hill from three different languages … In the 13th century it was called Pennul or Penhul, apparently from the Cumbric pen and Old English hyll, both meaning “hill”. The modern English “hill” was appended later, after the original meaning of Pendle had become opaque.

item.title: Adıyamanlı Süryânîler
item.description:
Primary sources on Syriacs of Ottoman Adıyaman

Adıyamanlı Süryânîler is a work I prepared that collects texts relating to the Syriac (Süryânî) community of Adıyaman and its environs in the early twentieth century. The document is composed of two parts, first being Adıyaman Tarihi, a biographical manuscript written by Bulıs Monofar and the second a collection of articles collected from early-twentieth century Syriac journals published in the Ottoman Empire and the United States.

item.title: The Ottoman Süryânî
item.description: I did my graduate studies at Boğaziçi Üniversitesi in Istanbul under the direction of the Vangelis Kechriotis. My research topic was the Ottoman Süryânî (Syriac) community during the Second Constitutional Period.
